header.topics: Swedish massage, hospice, nursery education, wife, female equality, terminology, the ME event next year and the involvement of women.
header.activity: Taking a break from the track work, working party.
header.conv_type: Discussing, Enplaining, Inquiring, complaining, advising, requesting,anecdote telling, making arrangements,

speaker.dialect_rep: I may have a slight Somerset accent
speaker.occupation: retired artist and antique dealer/gallery owner
Retired accomodation manager, nationwide building society

body.u: for talking to me so here we are erm in in the field that belongs to the parish council and is erm you're out here with the model engineers on a working party this morning
erm tell me why do you come?
to try and support the engineering club with a little bit of manual labour I like to support them in in other ways rather than just attending to play trains
yeah that's great because there are always jobs to be done out here aren't there?
yeah so how long have you been coming?
probably for the last er four months now I think it's
right so you're quite a new boy doing this then?
so erm what are your what are y what are the jobs you like doing best?
I don't mind really I I just like to be involved erm the I would say the other way the one thing I don't like very much is painting
oh right is it is it is it any particular reason? or
it's just something I don't enjoy I've always been involved with the building trade in one form or another since National Service
erm so I'm quite practically minded can
turn my hand to most things
and what what what was your role when you did your National Service?
I was in Royal Airforce Signals
erm which was particularly based in erm private or secret locations such as underground signal centres
erm so that all of the RAF signal traffic was kept confidant
right is that still the case or is that all opened up now?
I er think it with the new technology everything has changed
erm in d the days I was doing National Service it was all GPO telephone equipment er so you had GPO engineers but I would imagine now it's all high technology internet all sorts
right well erm so much I mean so much has been brought to the fore with the easement of the erm the secrets act hasn't it?
and erm where they did er I can't remember the place erm where they did all the decoding erm machines erm Bickley? not Bickley something like that
we went to Bletchley Park quite recently
we went have you been there?
ironically we only live forty miles away and I've never been there
erm watched documentaries on the programme er very interesting to see what they did but I've never actually been to the site
no and did you see the film recently?
yeah and what a tragic life
for what he contributed to this country's security
I know that wasn't that Cumberbatch didn't he play?
yeah he did he was very good wasn't he?
he wa he was absolutely brilliant it's well worth anyone watching that film
to get a better understanding of what was involved
yeah I mean you can as you say you can learn so much and er conversely we saw the suffragettes recently have

erm well we asked someone to come with us and she said she didn't want to come because it would horrible and they tortured them and all that sort of thing but actually it was a very good film and it was in the same vein
it was I reckon a drama documentary
yeah iit does iit records history which will be forgotten if someone does not record it
that's great I mean they can keep doing Downton Abbey until they're blue in the face by just making up plots it just turns

but erm with these sort of spot erm interests I was I I'm related to Lloyd George the prime minister erm very distantly but I am related to him I mean everybody laughs and says they're related to Lloyd George but I am and he was in the suffragette film or the actor playing Lloyd George
was in the suffragette film and that was very interesting
so I recommend it to you it's not erm a bit like the Turing film it it's not erm it does you don't come out feeling happy it's not a happy film
but at the same it's iinstructional and and you can
get the gist of the ideas at the time
well there is so much we don't know about for instance world war two
you know erm for example my father was a military policeman
erm and he served in north Africa and Italy Tunisia and he ended up in Romania and people say we we didn't have forces in Romania but we did
we had a military police detachment there
were basically doing what this country did in iraq I think when they sent out police first of all and there was a sad loss of seven policemen who were
by a gang er that's what my father did it was a small group of policemen
in Romania erm he had collected a large number of photographs posing with Russian officers
all sorts local people local events er when he died I asked my children erm these photographic albums are quite an unusual record
erm if I give them to you will what will you do with them?
and they said well we'll take care of them dad you know
and I so I chose then I asked their consent and I donated them all the military police museum
and they were actually thrilled to bits because apparently they get loads of paperwork about servicemen
and there's my dad in his military police uniform
posing with Russian officers it incredible record they were thrilled to bits so it they've got all his personal documentation his ID cards his medals he was mentioned in dispatches
they've got a complete record of one sergeant in
a real family pride then on an anc er as of an ancestor really
yes and I didn't want it to get lost in the future
speak up oh they've gone by
if it goes if it goes into history like that
that's a good record of world war two
from an unusual aspect of it you know
and he did survive the war
er it did torment him later in life
how do you fee if you can speak up a little more because we've got some people outside erm how do you see then when you see Flog It and people are selling their medals and

I I don't really like it but I th I don't think you can you you can't manage it can you? they they become erm valued items and people will sell them erm if the family don't take care of them and pass them on
it's sad that they've become an item for making money on
oh it does it is yeah
but that's again why I decided that my father's record and his medals
should all go to the military police

yes exactly yeah and and you and and that's right and and it's assured now and you you can rest rest assured I mean I've got a collection of erm Lloyd George memorabilia not that I've they're just things that
the family had that for some reason people gave to me no one else wanted them

and erm I got a lot of books erm and mmy idea one day was to go through them and maybe write something of my own but I'm actually more of a novel writer and a poetry I'm I'm in the middle of a novel at the moment I'm on page er on chapter fourteen? erm of my first novel and I've done a poetry book so far erm but erm that's what I'm doing but anyway erm back to you so do you do any writing at all?
no I I I'm not a writer cum author of any sort I do enjoy putting letters together
and there's plenty of opportunity with the problems that we have these days
and whether it be problems with power companies or whatever
and I quite enjoy putting letters together
but without being too rude about it
no exactly well you you know who was a past master at that was Charles Dickens

if you ever get a chance to look up Charles Dickens his letters to his clock maker or clock mender erm he wrote some very witty letters erm and I won't I I can't repeat it in the same way as Charles Dickens wrote it so it's best that you look it up because it's very entertaining
really very entertaining indeed erm so yeah but erm it is nice to bring if you're complaining about something it's nice to bring a bit of humour into it don't you find that?
oh I think so er you need to make the point strongly that you are trying to get home
on the other hand you don't demand
you may expect but not demand
er and I always try to put a sensible letter together and I always try to keep it to one page
I think people don't like to go
no it's the same if you're applying for a job it's always best to keep it on one page

one page erm and also in to my mind I always make the typeface slightly larger because it's easier to read erm er you know if if type if the type is very small people even younger people have got challenging eye problems haven't they? whoa it's getting a bit noisy outside isn't it?
anyway we've got another five minutes to do so
we'll have to sh you'll have to shout you see erm so erm are you involved in this erm show that they're going to put on next year?
I don't have any details at the moment
of the show and I don't know what's planned
but I would like to be involved anyway
yeah yeah okay well I'm sure they I'm sure that we will be erm erm it'll be all hands on deck won't it?
I would imagine so if there's some

I was hopi I mean always when they've done shows before I I've always brought my art along whwhen when they were in the schools like they had one in the school erm several years erm and I brought my art arou along and erm exhibited it but I didn't make any sales because it's not that sort of show I do think though maymaybe you might like to press the point erm you didn't hear it here that there might be some things for women because if the men come if you do something for women as well then it'll mean you'll get more support all the way round and I think that'll be a good idea really
I think it's important that you do try and involve the ladies these days you know otherwise erm they can become treated as er tea makers and
and that's n that's not on
it's better that they take a an interesting
er role in the organisation even if it's only from time to time

yeah somebody asked me er or a few years ago now if I'd like to make the teas for something that an organisation that was part of and I s I said to my husband well if I was holding an art group would he come and make the teas for me?
he wouldn't so I said no I'm not doing it erm
because erm you know women aren't just hangers on
they're people in their own right and to be treated like that it's it's going back Victorian times
erm and it's erm although I'm not terrifically women's lib I'm I believe in equality and that's not treating people equally at all
at at times in my last employment with the building society er I had a rather problematical manager to deal with
and his secretary started to follow his same attitude and she was quite rude to me one day
and I went to both him and the girl and I said I don't mind whether you call me or Mr
I don m you choose I said but I do expect you to respect my age and my experience in the way you speak to me
and I said and I don't mind whether I work for a lady manager
as long as they know what they are doing
as long as they know the job
and I've always felt that way and there is
to that degree equality is most important that women should have the opportunity
yeah yes iit is very important
I mean the erm use of the word lady is erm is great and I was brought up to use it because it was erm a term of respect
but these days I mean you think if you go to the doctor you call you say well I'd like to see a male doctor you never say I would like to see a female doctor you say I'd like to see a lady doctor
that should go it should be male or female
to be equal to the male

erm because it's a stigma really erm the use of the word lady erm or woman a woman doctor my mother always tell me to use the wor if you say oh that woman over there has got a bright red jacket on my mother would say to me it's very rude to use the word woman you've always got to say lady
well that's not that's not so anymore and it can't be so in th in these days of equality
because you'd say that man over there nobody would say well that's rude you can say gentleman
that man over there but iit's very strange erm and these things are being erm are being weeded out over the years aren't they?
yeah I I've got involved wiwith a number of other activities as well and and one was working in the hospice movement
and I've worked in the hospice movement for more than sixteen years now
and I had to change as I used to be a minibus driver and then the NHS got rid of most of the minibuses
and I had to either withdraw from the hospice or find something else to do
and I I chose to go to college at the age of sixty-six I think
and I do er Swedish body massage
oh really? oh right my goodness
erm that is the most extremely rewarding thing I have ever done with in particular terminally ill patients
and I think it's it's not so much the massage but it's the warmth of somebody's touch
but initially it was a little bit of a problem because I'm sure the hospice felt that oh we shouldn't have a man
but in the end it went complete reversal and the ladies
and it was a matter of building trust
and take someone into a therapy room
what a wonderful thing to do
what a wo you still do it do you?
I still do it but because we've moved into a different area
erm it's still in its infancy
with the health and wellbeing centre in
so I I'm due to be there this afternoon
you are you do get around don't you? that's wonderful
there may or may not be people who would like to try
in fact the club could even do it if they have a thing with ladies here
they could have hand massage for nothing
yes exactly that would be lovely
or to hands or feet or
well that's a wonderful idea now you see I wonder how many of those people out there know that about you and I know in fifteen minutes today
most of the men wouldn't know er
because you have to obey erm all the er the rules about er privacy
I would talk about an individual but
erm and it would only be a hint of

you're you're right thing about not being touched so many people are s maybe live on their own or go into a hospice they they they're they're coming to the end of their life and you know they've got no one no one ever touches them
they've gone c they've got completely no human contact
no and I felt that was important in the hospice environment because so often it's perhaps elderly ladies
who have been living on their own as a widow for perhaps twenty
and no one has touched them
in the room er surrounded by nursing staff and other staff
I I have found it extremely rewarding the reactions
yeah the other thing too which I mean it's it's very different but it's the same sort of thing people who take their friendly dogs into places
and they're allowed to stroke them
and the touching of that is so beneficial
def it's such a highlight that is
and I mean there's something about a dog that always wa you know wants you to smile you want to smile don't you? there's something about a dog or a pet
and they have got a level of understanding that far outreaches
they're amazing and and they're being used so much now to diagnose different cancers aren't they?
and all sorts of diseases and it's
erm diabetes no erm er er er a helping dog now can be a diabetic dog who can erm a diabetic erm diagnosing dog should I say
who can notice the acetone on the breath or the smell of the person that they're looking at
now what have we done? we've done seventeen minutes are you happy with that?
